newsitem.title: GERMANY: Germany favours renewed EU foreign policy "troika".
newsitem.headline: Germany favours renewed EU foreign policy "troika".

text.p: German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel has said Bonn wants to restructure the three-minister troika which represents EU foreign policy to give the body more continuity.
The body currently comprises the foreign ministers of the past, present and future holders of the six-month rotating presidency of the European Union.

In a release of Monday's edition, the daily Handelsblatt quoted Kinkel as suggeting that the troika could comprise an EU external affairs commissioner, the foreign minister of the current EU president and a general-secretary for foreign and security policy.

EU members broadly agree that the current Intergovernmental Conference (IGC) on institutional reform should give birth to a foreign policy coordinator, and Kinkel's suggestion was similar to one made by France in September.

But France wants to see the third position filled by a higher-profile "high representative" to coordinate and personify the policy -- a political figure rather than the humbler coordinator Germany has in mind.
Kinkel also said Germany wanted to give more powers to the president of the European Commission, currently very much a "first among equals", to boost the standing of the EU's executive body.
"The counterweight to the Council of Ministers of an extended EU must be a strong Commission," Kinkel was quoted as saying.
He suggested that the Commission president could be elected by the European parliament before the other commissioners instead of simultaneously.
The president should be allowed more influence over the composition of the commission, perhaps by being allowed to name his colleagues from short-list put forward by member states, he said.
